text: I need to correct that. I mean, I appreciate the thought, but it's not a mean reversion feature at all. I'm actually looking for a break in that co-integration structure. So something is co-integrated now and it stops being co-integrated, which means those time series start to diverge again. And I'm looking to get onto that trend. I'm not looking for a spread to close. I'm looking for a spread to widen, but the signaling is using co-integration as an input measure. Sure. Well, perhaps the marriage of those is you have a large number of market participants who are trading the co-integration assumption. And when it breaks, you end up with a bunch of forced sellers. People have to unwind their positions and you end up riding the trend of their unwind. It could be. And maybe as years go by, I'll find out more talking to people as to why that works, but you could be right. I mean, there could be a lot of carry traders in the market. There could be a lot of stat arb and spread traders in the market that are actually looking for a spread to close. Because it has widened and it optically looks attractive to do a mean reversion trade. And they do that. And I take the opposite side of that trade, looking for that spread to become even wider, but I'm probably not doing it at the top. I'm looking for a period of time where kind of like the spreads have closed and hopefully they will get wider and the co-integration that I have detected will break.
